content.description: Desc. Needed#3 According to the picture posted on the kiosk.

Follow the start of Acrophobia 5.7 till you reach a ledge. Clip one of the bolts on the anchors and extend it as this is your last bolt. Traverse out right and continue up until you meet a v slot. Get some gear in here and prepare for the crux. Be careful as there is a large loose block that makes come out one day. I've tried to pull this block out and it won't come out so don't worry too much, just be mindful of it. Fire up the slot on terrible holds and pull yourself up to easier terrain. Continue to the same anchors as Acrophobia 5.7. Not for the faint of heart or a nonexperienced trad leader. Not exactly sure why this is labeled as a sport route or a 5.9 as neither of those are true.#8 According to the picture posted on the kiosk.
content.protection: Bolted Anchors with Rap Rings, Light single rack nothing larger than a 3 don't skimp on the micro gear or nuts
content.location: Same start as Acrophobia 5.7 then a little bit right

content.description: Starting on an interesting sequence follow small holds and technical moves till you get established on the face. Make a very balancy move off of small footholds to work your way up the face. Use the arrette to guide your progress to the top from here until you reach the anchors.#6 According to the picture posted on the kiosk.
content.protection: 4 Bolts, Bolted Anchors with Rap Rings
content.location: Just to the left of the very obvious arrette in the middle of the wall.

content.description: Desc. Needed#12 According to the picture posted on the kiosk.
Desc. Needed#9 According to the picture posted on the kiosk.
content.location: To the right of Stall Factor 5.10b. Look for the most disgusting looking area with a bolt on it.

content.description: There are multiple ways to start this route. Follow the path of least resistance using rails and technical moves to get to the ledge. Continue straight up the face where you can get a good finger lock rest on weird-looking rock. Then, clip the bolts on a really bad sloper and don't fall. #1 According to the picture posted on the kiosk.
content.protection: 4 Bolts, Bolted Anchors with Rap Rings
content.location: The farthest left route of the face on the Goliath wall

content.description: Slabby balanced climb mostly uses a large flake that comes out of the middle of the wall. Short and sweet. Rock quality is not very good. #2 According to the picture posted on the kiosk.
content.protection: 4 Bolts, Bolted Anchors with Rap Rings
content.location: Directly In front of the concrete amphitheater

content.description: Desc. Needed#11 According to the picture posted on the kiosk.
Desc. Needed#10 According to the picture posted on the kiosk.

Easy climbing up until about mid-way. A really weird sequence gets you established on the face. After that slither up a water groove and finish at the anchors.#5 According to the picture posted on the kiosk.
content.protection: 5 Bolts, Bolted Anchors with Rap Rings
content.location: Find the obvious water groove. The route starts directly below it.

content.description: The most obvious route at Goliath wall. This route runs along a large crack that goes straight up through the middle of the quarry. Slightly technical start and from there it's either dihedral technique or laybacking. After a couple of moves, mantle up onto a ledge and continue up, and traverse right to the anchors.#7 According to the picture posted on the kiosk.
content.protection: 4 Bolts, Bolted Anchors with Rap Rings
content.location: Starts below an obvious chimney/offwidth looking crack. Very easy to find.

content.description: Easy start up to a large horizontal crack. From there, pull over a small lip and continue up a semi-technical face. A couple of technical moves on shallow pockets gets you to the anchors from here.#4 According to the picture posted on the kiosk.
content.protection: 5 Bolts, Bolted Anchors with Rap Rings
content.location: Just to the right of the concrete amphitheater. Easily Identifiable by the 3 bolts very close together.

content.description: Nice open field and climbing wall with some decent routes. The sun shines right on the wall, so it's best to climb this area in cooler weather/seasons. The rock is not the best quality towards the bottom half of the cliff shelf. It gets better as you go up the routes though. A good place for some practice or new climbers. An old abandoned rock quarry, much of the Wall’s face was hidden behind years of accumulated overburden and debris. The Goliath Wall became a reality in 2005 when a generous donation from Gordon and Gerry Chipman, in memory of Gerry’s son, David, allowed the outdoor leadership program to begin the project by contracting with a local excavator to remove the overburden from against the wall. It officially opened in 2006.
